skill.name: prpm-json-best-practices
skill.description: Best practices for structuring prpm.json package manifests with required fields, tags, organization, multi-package management, enhanced file format, eager/lazy activation, and conversion hints
skill.summary: Best practices for structuring prpm.json package manifests with required fields, tags, organization,...
skill.author: AgentWorkforce

security_audit.summary: This skill is purely documentation and educational content about PRPM package manifest structure. All 519 static findings are false positives from pattern matching against documentation examples, JSON schema definitions, and bash command examples. No executable code or actual security risks present.

content.value_statement: Creating proper PRPM package manifests is complex with many required fields and best practices. This skill provides comprehensive guidance on structuring prpm.json files for single packages, multi-package repositories, collections, and advanced features.
actual_capabilities: Guide creation of prpm.json manifests for single and multi-package repositories
Explain required fields, format types, and subtype values for all package types
Provide organization patterns for tags, file paths, and version management
Detail eager vs lazy activation, enhanced file format, and conversion hints
Validate manifest structure and detect common mistakes like duplicate names
Show collection creation for bundling existing packages together
limitations: Documentation only - does not automatically generate or validate prpm.json files
Requires understanding of package management concepts and semver versioning
Does not cover PRPM CLI usage or publishing workflows in detail
Focuses on manifest structure, not package content quality

use_cases.title: Publish first PRPM package
use_cases.description: Learn required fields, file structure, and validation steps to create a valid prpm.json and publish your first package

use_cases.title: Manage multi-package repositories
use_cases.description: Organize multiple related packages in one repository with proper naming, tagging, and version synchronization

use_cases.title: Create package collections
use_cases.description: Bundle existing published packages into curated collections with version ranges and dependency management

prompt_templates.title: Create basic manifest
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a prpm.json manifest for a Claude skill called typescript-safety that enforces TypeScript best practices. Include all required fields.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-package setup
prompt_templates.prompt: I have three separate prpm.json files for different packages. Show me how to combine them into one multi-package manifest with proper organization.

prompt_templates.title: Collection creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a collection that bundles typescript-strict version 1.0.0, react-best-practices version 2.0.0, and testing-utils latest into a development-setup collection.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced configuration
prompt_templates.prompt: My package targets both Cursor and Claude. Add conversion hints so it uses alwaysApply for Cursor and allows Read/Write tools for Claude.

output_examples.input: What required fields do I need for a Claude skill?
output: author: Your GitHub username or name
license: SPDX identifier like MIT or Apache-2.0
format: Must be 'claude' for Claude skills

output_examples.input: How do I organize tags for a TypeScript testing package?
output: Use kebab-case format for all tags
Include 3-8 tags combining technology, domain, and purpose

best_practices: Always use full file paths from project root starting with .claude/ or .cursor/ directories
Validate manifest with duplicate name checks and file existence verification before publishing
Keep related packages at the same version and organize by privacy, format, then subtype
anti_patterns: Do not add installed packages from prpm.lock to prpm.json - they serve different purposes
Avoid using prepublish scripts instead of prepublishOnly as they run on user install too
Never use absolute paths or missing directory prefixes in files array

faq.question: Do I need prpm.json if I just install packages?
faq.answer: No, prpm.json is only needed if you are publishing packages. Regular users only need prpm.lock which is auto-generated.

faq.question: What is the difference between packages and collections?
faq.answer: Packages define files to include from your repository. Collections bundle existing published packages by packageId references.

faq.question: Can I have both packages and collections in one prpm.json?
faq.answer: Yes, use the packages array to define your packages and collections array to bundle them or reference external packages.

faq.question: When should I use eager loading for skills?
faq.answer: Use eager: true only for critical skills that must always be active like coding standards. Most skills should be lazy loaded on demand.

faq.question: Why do my file paths need .claude or .cursor prefixes?
faq.answer: File paths must be full paths from project root where prpm.json lives. This is needed for tarball creation and installation.

faq.question: What are conversion hints used for?
faq.answer: Conversion hints provide format-specific metadata when converting packages between different AI tool formats like Cursor to Claude.
